Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 07:27PM AliT wrote: Hi!  Gearing up for treatment #3 this Friday. Round two was much worse than round one but now I know what to expect and we will be using Neulasta from now on (didn't use it #2 and got an infection!!).  I am so much more encouraged to come here and read all of your posts, they really make this so much more manageable. I will be half way done after #3 and while chemo hasn't been as bad as I thought it would be, I'm definitely ready to leave it behind.   Lots of uncomfortable reflux/acid indigestion even two weeks after treatment, is anyone else experiencing this? I am on 30mg of Prilosec a day until treatment is done! Maybe the meds are burning up my stomach (ugh), I guess they are derivatives of mustard gas. :)  I'm so thankful for this message board, even if I don't post as often as I would like to, I really appreciate having it. Lots of smiles, Allison T.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2011 06:25PM AliT wrote: Hi!  I had my first of six treatments today and I feel really great!! I am getting Taxotere/Cytoxen and then Nulasta. I'm definitely feeling a bit tired but I think most of it is from staying up too late and maybe the anti-nausea drug they infused. I am hopeful that the SEs will be minimal. I already shaved my head last weekend so that is one less thing I have to worry about, I thought doing it at a time when I was feeling good would be better for my spirits. I really love it and even though I have hats, I am most comfortable with no hair! I love the time it takes for me to get ready now. :)  The only bummer is I have been dealing with cellulitis in my left breast and then an infected seroma (staph), well, yesterday it was all gone and then today my breast was pink all over again! Ugh. I see Kym61 seems to have the same thing, is anyone else going through this? I'm back on antibiotics just in case it is the staph and was a little anxious when my Oncologist almost postponed today's treatment (again). But he seemed hopeful that the meds would work and this is also the reason I am getting Nulasta. I had a lumpectomy and will be going ahead with a bi-lateral mastectomy once chemo is done, now I wish I would've just gone ahead from the get go. Oh well. :) Is a heating pad a good solution? All in all, today was great as I just didn't know what to expect, the nurses were wonderful as well as very encouraging, especially when speaking of the side effects. One also told me that Claritin helps with bone pain when taking Nulasta. Good to know! I really hope everyone is feeling good (as good as can be expected), it is so nice to have this board to turn to for support.  Allison
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 10:33AM AliT wrote: So sorry to hear you have to join us here Amara! I am also 36 and am doing chemo before my mastectomy but only because my surgeon didn't get clean margins and there was just too much of a spread. I am opting to have my other breast removed at the same time so I don't have to worry about recurrence. I checked out Susan Love's Breast Book and that helped me get through the first few weeks of my diagnosis/surgery, I had so many questions and while finding some answers on the internet were helpful, I would find some discouraging information and it would kind of "set me back." This is the only discussion board I am part of and I love it! Things will settle down and you will find your own "groove". Chemo is not that bad at all, granted we all have different bodies that will respond in their own way but so far I have found that worst part was the unknown. You will be okay, we all will. Half a year of not feeling so great, losing my hair, and having another surgery are worth being able to stay alive for many, many years. I have two little girls so I will do anything I can to be able to watch them grow old.  You can do this!!! And...I heard your hair might grow back a different texture/color. I am excited for that, I had long blonde, straight hair and I am ready for some curls and a darker color. :) Allison
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2011 04:22PM AliT wrote: Hi All,  I made it to the good side of TC#3, phew! The nausea really got me again but I'm hopeful that the worst is over. Good news, my Onc thinks we will be okay stopping with four treatments then on to some imagining and then surgery. I am very happy about this but a little apprehensive for the obvious reason...what if it isn't enough! I hope everyone is having a good week and I hope all the side effects are minimal! I have been thinking of you all so much during these tough treatments. We can do it!!! Ali
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2011 07:34PM AliT wrote: Hi! I will hopefully be starting chemo this Wednesday, January 5th. I say hopefully because I have been battling a staph infection after my lumpectomy and have heard my Oncologist might push it out another week. I will be getting 6 rounds of TC (taxotere/cytoxin through port) and then will have a bi-lateral mastectomy, radiation and then Tamoxifen after that. I was pretty anxious but I have been told it isn't quite as bad as we think it is going to be. I have two little ones to take care of and my Onc has made it clear that I will be able to function. :)  This seems like a great place to get support, I wish none of us had to be here but already BC for me has been more of a blessing than I ever imagined it could be. I am striving to be one of those women who posts years down the road to the newcomers who need encouragement.  Hopefully January won't be as bad as imagined.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 09:31PM AliT wrote: Hi everyone!  Vis0121: I am sorry that you are not feeling well, I would also recommend calling your Onc's office as they should be able to help you with something. There is no reason why you should have to be suffering so much! Goatlisa:  I also have to deal with a staph infection after my lumpectomy (soon to be BMX once chemo is done) and it has been a little frustrating! I'm sure the infection is cleared but my breast is all pink and I am on another round of antibiotics. My Onc seemed to think it was okay to start and so far, I feel fine (day three post-infusion). Hopefully it will stay this way. Good luck to you!  I'm on day three and am feeling pretty good. I definitely had some nausea last night and a bit today but this evening I am feeling good. I got out both yesterday and today for some walking and that also helped. I'm feeling some neck and head pain and a friend who also had BC said it is from the Neulasta, she said it hurt to lay her head down on a pillow. :( Anyone else feeling this? I am taking Claritin and have no other pain so I'm assuming this too shall pass.  This is worth it, this is worth it, this is worth it!!! It sucks but I know we will all come out on the other side soon. Hang in there everyone! Lots of smiles.  P.S. Why can't I get my picture to post?? :) Augh.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 10:15AM AliT wrote: Hi!  I'm wondering if anyone on the Taxotere/Cytoxan treatment (or really, any for that matter) has explored only doing 4 rounds as opposed to 6? I have read a few articles saying that there really is no difference between the two, just more of an accumulation of side effects. I kind of hit a wall this last weekend with all my side effects and infections...I'm finding it hard to feel encouraged about doing 6 rounds (I have 4 more to go). I'm also getting a BMX, radiation, and then Tamoxifen for five years. Seems like a lot of chemo when I'm doing so many other preventative measures. Any words of wisdom? :) Allison
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 10:55PM AliT wrote: ScienceGirl- I had my lumpectomy already without clean margins and with some cancer inside the ducts so she recommended a left mastectomy, I opted for bilateral. I got staph infection after surgery so we had to put off doing anything for a few weeks longer than expected so they opted for chemo before BMX. I had lymph node involvement (3/12) and had a clear bone scan but no other scans. I guess we can discuss doing 4 and then a scan. Or I can stop being a whimp. :) I guess this second round really knocked me down.   Anyone else get Palmar Plantar Erythema? I have this now and it sounds like it might be my new friend until chemo is over with. Red and itchy!!  I can't remember who asked about heartburn meds but I am on Prilosec 20mg/day (the generic) and it takes a few days to kick in so I had to take some Pepcid along with it. I also got my doctor to call in a prescription so my insurance will help pay, this stuff is expensive!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2011 04:27PM AliT wrote: Juleski:  I too was scheduled to do 6 rounds of TC (Taxotere/Cytoxan) and I talked it over with my oncologist and he agreed to let me stop at 4, do a breast MRI and see what it looks like (I get the results tomorrow). I am going to have a BMX, rads, and then Tamoxifen for five years so I felt that two more rounds was toxic overload! If it means the difference between life and death then of course (!) I would finish the last two rounds, but at this point it doesn't look that way. I would say the difference between you and I though is that I am HER2- so maybe this is the deciding factor in going all six (but won't you have Herceptin too?).  Hoping to be moving forward.... :) Hang in there everyone.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 05:03PM AliT wrote: Hi!   I could finally upload a picture! Yay. Especially with the fog of chemo. :)  I am a week out from Taxotere/Cytoxen treatment and am feeling really good. My taste buds are shot though so things still taste very strange, especially water and I love water!! I haven't had too hard of a time with side effects but I have definitely experienced some nausea, restless leg feeling, headaches, and just plain flu-like symptoms. I was given Neulasta and this seems to have given me the most trouble with my hips and neck aching a lot. I'm curious to see what my blood counts are on Monday and to ask if this shot is worth trying every single treatment. Do other women get Neulasta shots on and off? I had a lot of weird head pain, almost like my head was being squeezed and was told this might have been from the Dexamethasone. Anyone else get this? It is gone but I'm not looking forward to this the next five treatments. I hope everyone is doing well. I love being able to come to this board for encouragement when my spirits are low. This could be SO much worse I know, but it still isn't fun. I'm just glad we are all able to get the chance to fight this disease...we are already winning!!!!!!!! Allison
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2011 05:50PM - edited Apr 10, 2011 05:54PM by AliT Hi Everyone,  I just wanted to check in after my BMX this last Friday (4/8). It is now Sunday so I am officially two days post-op and feeling really good. I had a lumpectomy and axillary node dissection back in December and this is not nearly as painful as that was. I was anxious and worried for nothing! I was a little more nauseous after surgery and couldn't really eat until the following morning, but otherwise felt fantastic.  I also slept in my own bed last night as I thought the recliner would offer little sleep. Good choice! I propped myself up a little more and slept the entire night.   Encouragement to those going in for surgery this week and after...you can do it!!!  Allison
Posts.Title: April 2011 Masectomy IllinoisNancy Beaglesgirl

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2011 08:11PM AliT wrote: Michelle- I did not get TE's or any kind of reconstruction, I might change my mind down the road but as for now I will just stay with a mastectomy. I wish you luck, I really am pleased with my progress and even though I am not normally an anxious person, I have become one through this cancer journey and I had myself all worked up for nothing!  I have a really sweet surgeon and she told me it wouldn't be as bad I might have thought and she was right!! Get comfy in your chair and let your DH take care of you.  Keep calm and carry on. I love this saying. Allison
Posts.Title: April 2011 Masectomy IllinoisNancy Beaglesgirl

Posts.Content: May 2, 2011 01:47PM AliT wrote: Melania: I am about 3 1/2 weeks post-op (BMX w/out reconstruction) and also have a 4 year-old (and a 5 year-old), they both spent a few nights away but once they came home I was able to get up and around pretty good. I couldn't reach up into cabinets so had to have my husband do that. I also had chemo before surgery (4 rounds TC) and pathology came back clean, I am however, doing more chemo as a precaution and then radiation once that is over. All in all things have gone pretty good, I feel like a stronger person and each day the healing gets better. Take one day at a time.  Sweetbadger: My Oncologist told be to get a compression or sports bra because I am having a little residual fluid build up around the surgical site. It seems to help a little bit.  Is anyone signed up for more chemo? I had four rounds of TC then BMX and now my Onc wants me to do more chemo as a precaution. I was a little disappointed but since it was in my lymph nodes he wants to be extra diligent. Ugh. The meds this time "shouldn't make me as sick" and I mentally am ready for it but just wondering if anyone else is heading down this road. I guess I get to head back to the chemo boards. :)  Great job everyone!! We made it!  Allison
Posts.Title: April 2011 Masectomy IllinoisNancy Beaglesgirl

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2011 08:43PM AliT wrote: Hi!!   I am scheduled to have a BMX this Friday April 8th, no reconstruction. I had a previous lumpectomy that did not have clean margins (and had lymph node involvement) and due to an infection we needed to just get chemo started before any more surgery. I feel like I am ready for this to happen but still a little apprehensive.   I'm glad to find other women out there that are going through the same thing. The chemo thread I jumped over from was extremely helpful.   Good luck to everyone!!! Ali
Posts.Title: April 2011 Masectomy IllinoisNancy Beaglesgirl

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2011 02:27PM AliT wrote: Hi!  I am now 7 days post-op BMX (no reconstruction) and today I feel almost 100% except for some residual pain in the arm pit areas. I take some Tylenol before bed as the end of the day seems to be when the most pain shows up, but I also need to take it easy more.  For swelling under the arms I have been using a soft ice gel pack, 20 minutes at a time. This seems to be helping me tremendously. I was so swollen I could hardly feel my port.  Advil helps too.  Good luck to those of you heading in to surgery soon, it is NOT as bad as you think it is. Yay for all those who made it through surgery this week!!! This has been a long journey but all these steps are worth it, I know I want to be around to watch my two little girls grow old.  Allison
Posts.Title: April 2011 Masectomy IllinoisNancy Beaglesgirl
